definitions.definition: to place something over or in front of something in order to hide, protect or decorate it

examples.text: Cover the chicken loosely with foil.
She covered her face with her hands.
I covered my mouth to stifle a yawn.
He laughed to cover *(= hide)* his nervousness.
He tried to cover his embarrassment by starting to rub his hands together.
Her hair partially covered her face.
She tried to cover her face with her hands.
She used dried leaves and twigs to cover up the hole.

definitions.definition: to lie or spread over the surface of something
definitions.sensetop: cover somethingbe covered with somethingbe covered in something

examples.text: Snow covered the ground.
Much of the country is covered by forest.
Its head, body, and tail are **completely covered** with brown fur.
His chest was covered in bruises.

definitions.definition: to put or spread a layer of liquid, dust, etc. on somebody/something
definitions.sensetop: cover somebody/something with somethingcover somebody/something in somethingbe covered with somethingbe covered in something

examples.text: The wind blew in from the desert and covered everything with sand.
Soak the dried mushrooms by covering them in boiling water for a few minutes.
The steps were now completely covered with water.
The players were soon covered in mud.
The cars were all covered in snow.
The children were completely covered with mud.

definitions.definition: to include something; to deal with something

examples.text: The lectures **covered a lot of ground** *(= a lot of material, subjects, etc.)*.
The survey covers all aspects of the business.
The articles **cover a** wide **range** of subjects.
Each podcast **covers a** different **topic**.
the sales team covering the northern part of the country *(= selling to people in that area)*
Do the rules cover *(= do they apply to)* a case like this?
Don't worry. **I've got it covered** *(= I'm dealing with it)*.
The tax may be extended to cover books.
We've hardly covered a quarter of the course.

definitions.definition: to be or provide enough money for something

examples.text: $100 should **cover your expenses**.
The show barely **covered its costs**.
Your parents will have to cover your tuition fees.
By sunset we had covered thirty miles.
They walked for a long time and **covered** a good deal of **ground**.
He covered the journey at top speed.
They covered long distances on foot.
We must have covered over 20 miles.
I covered a lot of ground rapidly and soon caught up with them.

definitions.definition: to spread over the area mentioned

examples.text: The reserve **covers an area** of some 1 140 square kilometres.

definitions.definition: to report on an event for television, a newspaper, etc.; to show an event on television

examples.text: She's covering the party's annual conference.
The BBC will cover all the major games of the tournament.
The media has consistently refused to **cover the story**.

definitions.definition: to do somebody’s work or duties while they are away

examples.text: I'm covering for Jane while she's on leave.

definitions.definition: to invent a lie or an excuse that will stop somebody from getting into trouble

examples.text: I have to go out for a minute—will you cover for me if anyone asks where I am?

definitions.definition: to protect somebody against loss, injury, etc. by insurance
definitions.sensetop: cover somebody/something (against/for something)cover somebody/something to do something

examples.text: Are you fully covered for fire and theft?
Does this policy cover my husband to drive?
This policy should cover you against accidental injury.
a policy that covers you for fire and theft

definitions.definition: to take action in order to protect yourself against being blamed for something

examples.text: Many firms put money aside to cover themselves against possible legal claims.

definitions.definition: to protect somebody by threatening to shoot at anyone who tries to attack them

examples.text: Cover me while I move forward.
The artillery gave us covering fire *(= shot to protect us)*.

definitions.definition: to aim a gun at a place or person so that nobody can escape or shoot

examples.text: The police covered the exits to the building.
Don't move—we've **got you covered**!

definitions.definition: to record a new version of a song that was originally recorded by another band or singer

examples.text: They've covered an old Rolling Stones number.

definitions.definition: to consider and deal with all the things that could happen or could be needed when you are arranging something

examples.text: I am confident this contract covers all the bases.

definitions.definition: to realize that you may be blamed or criticized for something later and take action to avoid this

examples.text: Get everything in writing in order to cover your back.

definitions.definition: to hide the real situation or facts when these are not good or pleasant

examples.text: It's a shabby old sofa but cushions and throws can hide a multitude of sins.

definitions.definition: to try and hide what you have done, because you do not want other people to find out about it

examples.text: He had attempted to cover his tracks by wiping the hard disk on his computer.

wordOrigin: Middle English: from Old French covrir, from Latin cooperire, from co- (expressing intensive force) + operire ‘to cover’. The noun is partly a variant of covert.
